üîß Installation Basics in Linux

1. üñ•Ô∏è Designing the Disk Partitioning Scheme

Partitioning = Dividing your hard drive into sections for different purposes.

Common Linux partitions:

  • / ‚Äì Root: Main system files (required).
  • /home ‚Äì Personal files for users (optional but useful).
  • /boot ‚Äì Stores files needed to start Linux (required).
  • swap ‚Äì Used as virtual memory when RAM is full (optional).
  • /var, /opt, /usr ‚Äì Used for special software/data (optional).

‚úÖ Example layout:

/boot      ‚Äì 512 MB
/          ‚Äì 20 GB (or more)
/home      ‚Äì Remaining space
swap       ‚Äì 2 GB (or more, based on your RAM)

2. üíΩ Ensuring /boot Conforms to Hardware Requirements

  • The /boot partition stores the kernel and bootloader (e.g., GRUB).

  • On UEFI systems, you need an EFI System Partition:

    • Format: FAT32
    • Size: 512 MB to 1 GB
    • Mount point: /boot/efi
  • On BIOS systems, /boot is just a normal ext4 partition.

üëâ Make sure your boot partition is properly formatted and large enough.

3. üîÅ Concept of Swap Space

  • Swap is disk space used like extra RAM.
  • Helps when your system runs out of memory.
  • Can be a partition or a swap file.

Recommended sizes:

  • RAM < 2 GB ‚Üí swap = 2x RAM
  • RAM 2‚Äì8 GB ‚Üí swap = same as RAM
  • RAM > 8 GB ‚Üí swap = 2‚Äì4 GB (or more if using hibernation)

4. üì¶ Understanding LVM (Logical Volume Manager)

  • LVM is a flexible way to manage disk space.

  • Instead of fixed partitions, LVM allows you to:

    • Resize volumes easily (without reboot).
    • Combine multiple drives into one logical group.
    • Create snapshots (useful for backups/testing).

LVM structure:

Physical Volume (PV) ‚Üí Volume Group (VG) ‚Üí Logical Volume (LV)

‚úÖ Benefits:

  • Easier resizing
  • Better disk management
  • Ideal for servers or advanced setups
